questions.article: Maryam Hosseini and colleagues trained a computer program to identify sidewalks in aerial images of Boston and used it on images of Washington, DC. Its performance on the images of Washington, DC, was ______ that on images of Boston; the accuracy was nearly the same for both, and the program could consistently distinguish whether the sidewalks were made of cobblestone or brick.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: uncertain about

options.name: B
options.content: similar to

options.name: C
options.content: unique from

options.name: D
options.content: supportive toward

questions.correct: similar to

questions.article:
The following text is from Jhumpa Lahiri’s 2003 novel The Namesake. Gogol, a child, is at a beach in Massachusetts with his father.

He watches his father raise a kite within minutes into the wind, so high that Gogol must tip his head back in order to see, a rippling speck against the sky. The wind whips around their ears, turning their faces cold.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word “raise” most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Strengthen

options.name: B
options.content: Lift

options.name: C
options.content: Celebrate

options.name: D
options.content: Group

questions.correct: Lift

questions.article: Domesticated thousands of years ago in South America, the potato deviates structurally from the wild plant it is descended from. Summer squash differs even more from its own ancestor, which had a hard rind and bitter flesh. Indigenous people in eastern North America selectively bred the crop until it ______ the soft rind and mild-tasting flesh that now characterize it.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: inspired

options.name: B
options.content: acquired

options.name: C
options.content: surrendered

options.name: D
options.content: retrieved

questions.correct: acquired

questions.article: The HMS Conqueror is just one of approximately three million known historical shipwrecks spread throughout the world’s oceans, and their impact on underwater life and ecosystems is of great interest to researchers. Rachel Mugge and colleagues were particularly curious about the effects of wooden shipwrecks on three different seafloor microbial communities: bacteria, archaea, and fungi. The researchers studied two wooden shipwrecks in the Gulf of Mexico by placing pieces of pine and oak between zero and 200 meters away from each shipwreck to collect samples of microbes. They found that wood type had a much more significant influence on bacterial community composition than on archaeal or fungal community composition.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To argue that wooden shipwrecks affect fish more than they do microbial communities

options.name: B
options.content: To describe how the first shipwreck in the Gulf of Mexico was discovered

options.name: C
options.content: To detail the composition of the HMS Conqueror

options.name: D
options.content: To provide an overview of a study about the effects of wooden shipwrecks on seafloor microbial communities

questions.correct: To provide an overview of a study about the effects of wooden shipwrecks on seafloor microbial communities

questions.article: In the US, the Trademark Act of 1946 allows companies to own trademarks, which are words or images that represent specific products. “Kleenex,” for example, refers to products made specifically by Kimberly-Clark, the company that owns the trademark. However, the Trademark Act of 1946 also allows a trademark to be taken away if it ceases to be specific. For example, “cellophane” was once a trademark for a particular brand of food wrapping material. Over time, though, people started using “cellophane” to refer to many different brands. Because the word had become generic, a court decided that it could no longer be owned as a trademark.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It concludes the text’s argument about how the Trademark Act of 1946 can be improved.

options.name: B
options.content: It completes the text’s comparison of trademark laws in the US to laws in other countries.

options.name: C
options.content: It adds to the text’s description of products made by Kimberly-Clark.

options.name: D
options.content: It begins the text’s discussion of the fact that trademarks can be taken away.

questions.correct: It begins the text’s discussion of the fact that trademarks can be taken away.

questions.article:
Text 1

From the extinct giant ground sloth to the living pygmy three-toed sloth, sloths are among the most appealing animals native to the Americas. But scientists still have a lot to learn about them. Unlike their ancient ground-dwelling relations, today’s sloths spend most of their time high up in trees. The sloths’ inaccessibility has made it hard for scientists to study them.

Text 2

By using a backpack monitor, biologist Rebecca Cliffe and colleagues can at last discover the previously hidden activities of sloths. Such monitors can provide information to correct misconceptions. It was long believed that sloths are slow because of laziness. But, in fact, sloths have low metabolism, which makes them slow.
questions.question: The author of Text 1 and the author of Text 2 both discuss which topic?

options.name: A
options.content: Scientists’ efforts to understand sloths

options.name: B
options.content: Changes in sloths’ habitats

options.name: C
options.content: How extinct sloths compare with living sloths

options.name: D
options.content: The benefits of putting monitoring devices on sloths

questions.correct: Scientists’ efforts to understand sloths

questions.article: Rocky Ridge Farmhouse in Mansfield, Missouri, is the house where Laura Ingalls Wilder lived for nearly twenty years and wrote her novel Little House on the Prairie. Now the house is a museum dedicated to Wilder’s life and writings. It’s likely obvious why fans of Wilder’s works would choose to visit the museum. However, its curators also want to appeal to visitors who aren’t already familiar with Wilder. Guided tours and special events, such as outdoor plays based on Wilder’s books, are therefore important, since they help visitors find enjoyment in Wilder’s works.
questions.question: Based on the text, what is a benefit of visiting Rocky Ridge Farmhouse?

options.name: A
options.content: It is superior to most museums dedicated to Wilder’s life.

options.name: B
options.content: It helps visitors to appreciate Wilder’s works.

options.name: C
options.content: It includes exhibits on several important American writers.

options.name: D
options.content: It is near other museums dedicated to local history.

questions.correct: It helps visitors to appreciate Wilder’s works.

questions.article: A student is researching volcanoes in Ecuador. The student claims that all volcanoes in Ecuador are shield volcanoes.
questions.question: Which choice best describes information from the table that weakens the student’s claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Chacana and Chimborazo are both shield volcanoes.

options.name: B
options.content: Different volcano types have different years of last eruption.

options.name: C
options.content: Fernandina is the only shield volcano among the four Ecuadoran volcanoes shown in the table.

options.name: D
options.content: None of the four Ecuadoran volcanoes shown in the table are shield volcanoes.

questions.correct: Fernandina is the only shield volcano among the four Ecuadoran volcanoes shown in the table.

questions.article: A student is researching the Amiga and other important gaming systems that were part of the global rise of the home video game industry during the 1970s and 1980s. The student is surprised to find that the Amiga sold relatively few units worldwide, with only about ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the statement?

options.name: A
options.content: 1,600,000 units sold compared to the approximately 18,450,000 units sold of the Atari 2600.

options.name: B
options.content: 3,935,000 units sold compared to the approximately 4,487,000 units sold of the Apple II.

options.name: C
options.content: 3,935,000 units sold compared to the approximately 4,487,000 units sold of the Atari 2600.

options.name: D
options.content: 1,600,000 units sold compared to the approximately 18,450,000 units sold of the Sega SG-1000/Master System.

questions.correct: 1,600,000 units sold compared to the approximately 18,450,000 units sold of the Atari 2600.

questions.article: Memoirs of Elleanor Eldridge is an 1838 historical account by Elleanor Eldridge and Frances Harriet Whipple Green. In the book, the authors assert that all people naturally have an emotional attachment to where they live, writing, ______
questions.question: Which quotation from Memoirs of Elleanor Eldridge most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: “How careful ought we to be to speak nothing but the truth, even in regard to the most trifling circumstances; and not only so, but to be well assured that what we suppose to be true, is truth, before we receive it as such.”

options.name: B
options.content: “Home is home, to the lowly as well as the great; and no rank, or color, destroys its sacred character, its power over the mind, and the affections.”

options.name: C
options.content: “Blessed are the slumbers of the innocent! They are kindlier than balm, and they refresh and gladden the spirit of childhood, like ministerings from a better world.”

options.name: D
options.content: “To give some idea of the high esteem in which the subject of the following narrative is held, and the strong interest her misfortunes have excited, a few, from the great number of recommendations in her possession, are selected.”

questions.correct: “Home is home, to the lowly as well as the great; and no rank, or color, destroys its sacred character, its power over the mind, and the affections.”

questions.article: Biologist Rosanna Alegado believes that we might learn how multicellular organisms developed from single-celled ones if we understand why the single-celled organism Salpingoeca rosetta, the oldest living relative of animals, sometimes forms colonies of cells. Alegado and colleagues reviewed data from many studies about how S. rosetta responds when exposed to another type of single-celled organism, bacteria, including William C. Nierman’s work with Caulobacter crescentus bacteria and Josefa Antón’s work with Salinibacter ruber bacteria. Alegado and colleagues concluded that neither C. crescentus nor S. ruber are likely to have played a significant role in the development of multicellular organisms.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support Alegado and colleagues’ conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: S. rosetta tended to form colonies when exposed to S. ruber, but not when exposed to C. crescentus.

options.name: B
options.content: S. rosetta tended to form colonies when exposed to C. crescentus, but not when exposed to S. ruber.

options.name: C
options.content: S. rosetta did not tend to form colonies when exposed to either C. crescentus or S. ruber.

options.name: D
options.content: S. rosetta tended to form colonies when exposed to C. crescentus and when exposed to S. ruber.

questions.correct: S. rosetta did not tend to form colonies when exposed to either C. crescentus or S. ruber.

questions.article: Humans are overwhelmingly right-hand dominant (85–90%) and can thus be said to exhibit strong population-level right handedness (PLRH). Among studies of nonhuman primates, Margaret E. Redshaw’s 1993 study of captive gorillas purported to show PLRH, while William C. McGrew and colleagues’ 1999 study of wild chimpanzees did not. Overall, the studies claiming PLRH in nonhuman primates find much lower incidences of right-handedness than humans exhibit, but it’s worth noting that studies of captive primates tend to show significantly greater incidences of right-handedness than studies of wild primates do, therefore raising the possibility that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: the number of individuals in the study of wild chimpanzees is insufficient to preclude the claim that nonhuman primates exhibit PLRH.

options.name: B
options.content: the apparent discrepancy between the studies’ results may be partly attributable to the 1993 study using different criteria when assessing hand dominance than were used in the 1999 study.

options.name: C
options.content: the number of individuals in the study of captive gorillas is insufficient for a robust claim regarding evidence of PLRH.

options.name: D
options.content: the greater exposure to humans among the captive gorillas induced them to acquire more right-handed behaviors.

questions.correct: the greater exposure to humans among the captive gorillas induced them to acquire more right-handed behaviors.

questions.article: All stainless steel contains varying amounts of iron, carbon, and corrosion-inhibiting chromium. However, ferritic stainless steel, often used for induction cookers, contains a higher percentage of chromium (at least 10.5%) than does austenitic stainless steel and a higher concentration of iron, which is responsible for its magnetic properties. Unlike ferritic stainless steel, austenitic stainless steel has a face-centered cubic crystalline structure resulting from the addition of nickel to the alloy. Austenitic stainless steel has two subtypes: the 300 series, often used for aerospace tubing, and the 200 series, which has less nickel and more manganese than the 300 series and is used for home water tanks. Thus, stainless steel used to manufacture ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: aerospace tubing will have similar magnetic properties to stainless steel used to manufacture induction cookers.

options.name: B
options.content: both aerospace tubing and dishwashers will have a face-centered cubic crystalline structure, but stainless steel used to manufacture aerospace tubing will have less nickel than stainless steel used to manufacture dishwashers will

options.name: C
options.content: aerospace tubing will have a concentration of manganese greater than 10.5%, while stainless steel used to manufacture dishwashers will not.

options.name: D
options.content: aerospace tubing will have less manganese in its composition than stainless steel used to manufacture dishwashers will.

questions.correct: aerospace tubing will have less manganese in its composition than stainless steel used to manufacture dishwashers will.

questions.article: Indonesia joined the international police organization Interpol in 1952. As a member, Indonesia is required ______ other Interpol countries with access to its law enforcement databases.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: provided

options.name: B
options.content: to provide

options.name: C
options.content: providing

options.name: D
options.content: provides

questions.correct: to provide

questions.article: South Carolina politician Robert C. De Large was one of the nearly two thousand African Americans who won a public office between the years 1865 and 1877, which would ______
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: come to be known as the Reconstruction era?

options.name: B
options.content: come to be known as the Reconstruction era.

options.name: C
options.content: it come to be known as the Reconstruction era.

options.name: D
options.content: it come to be known as the Reconstruction era?

questions.correct: come to be known as the Reconstruction era.

questions.article: Museo de Arte Dr. Pío López Martínez is an art museum in Cayey, Puerto Rico. It’s one of more than eighty museums in the US territory. Puerto Rico’s ______ showcase everything from the territory’s art to its architecture to its coffee.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: museums

options.name: B
options.content: museums—

options.name: C
options.content: museums,

options.name: D
options.content: museums:

questions.correct: museums

questions.article: At Playhouse West in Los Angeles, California, students can learn the world-famous Meisner technique. This technique emphasizes reacting naturally to one’s environment in a scene and ______ actors to focus less on their own movement and speech.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: encourages

options.name: B
options.content: have encouraged

options.name: C
options.content: are encouraging

options.name: D
options.content: encourage

questions.correct: encourages

questions.article: During the American Civil War, thousands of women joined the war effort as ______ them was African American nurse Ann Bradford Stokes, who was later commended for her dedication to serving the medical needs of countless soldiers.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: nurses, among

options.name: B
options.content: nurses among

options.name: C
options.content: nurses. Among

options.name: D
options.content: nurses, and, among

questions.correct: nurses. Among

questions.article: When attempting to determine a fault’s seismic history, geophysicists like Dr. Estella Atekwana at the University of Delaware rely in part on data about the fault’s physical dimensions and geological features. For example, data from the US Geological Survey show the ______ and most recent deformation (less than 15 thousand years ago) of the Malibu Coast fault in Ventura County, California.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: length, (62 km); slip rate, (between 0.2 and 1.0 mm/yr);

options.name: B
options.content: length, (62 km), slip rate, (between 0.2 and 1.0 mm/yr),

options.name: C
options.content: length (62 km), slip rate (between 0.2 and 1.0 mm/yr),

options.name: D
options.content: length (62 km) slip rate (between 0.2 and 1.0 mm/yr)

questions.correct: length (62 km), slip rate (between 0.2 and 1.0 mm/yr),

questions.article: During the last Ice Age, glaciers covered what is now Finnmark, Norway. As these massive ice forms moved across the region, they bore down on Earth’s crust and, ______ left a deep, narrow 70 km inlet, or fjord, carved into the coastal landscape. Today, this spectacular cliff-sided body of water is known as Tanafjord.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: in general,

options.name: B
options.content: for example,

options.name: C
options.content: as a result,

options.name: D
options.content: in contrast,

questions.correct: as a result,

questions.article: In October 2011, professional skateboarder Elliot Sloan performed a trick called a 900. ______ he launched off a ramp, rotated 900 degrees in midair, and landed back on the ramp atop his board. As impressive as that may sound, a few skateboarders, including Jonathan Schwan, have even landed a 1080!
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Nevertheless,

options.name: B
options.content: On the other hand,

options.name: C
options.content: Previously,

options.name: D
options.content: In other words,

questions.correct: In other words,

questions.article: The geologic principle of cross-cutting relationships states that an intrusion is younger than the rocks through which it cuts. ______ geochemists analyzing a given rock formation can ascertain that an igneous intrusion that bisects a layer of 393.3-million-year-old Eifelian rock but not the 254.1-million-year-old Changhsingian rock above it is younger than the former but older than the latter.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Accordingly,

options.name: B
options.content: That being said,

options.name: C
options.content: To this end,

options.name: D
options.content: Moreover,

questions.correct: Accordingly,

questions.article: On May 19, 1965, the president of South Korea, Chung Hee Park, was recognized with a ticker-tape parade in New York City. This was just one of a number of diplomacy-related parades over the years. ______ between 1886 and 2022, there were seventy-three ticker-tape parades held in New York to honor foreign heads of state.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Nevertheless,

options.name: B
options.content: In other words,

options.name: C
options.content: In sum,

options.name: D
options.content: Hence,

questions.correct: In sum,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Each of Neptune’s fourteen moons takes a different amount of time to orbit Neptune.
  • The moon Despina completes an orbit of Neptune in 0.33 Earth days on average.
  • German mathematician and astronomer Johannes Kepler (1571–1630) developed three laws of planetary motion that describe the orbits of planets in a solar system.
  • Kepler’s laws also apply to the orbits of natural satellites (e.g., moons).
questions.question: The student wants to specify how long Despina’s orbit of Neptune takes. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Among Neptune’s fourteen moons is Despina, which completes its orbit of the planet in 0.33 Earth days on average.

options.name: B
options.content: Despina’s orbit of Neptune can be described using Kepler’s three laws of planetary motion.

options.name: C
options.content: It takes Despina three Earth days to orbit Neptune, a number that can be deduced from Kepler’s laws of planetary motion.

options.name: D
options.content: Kepler’s three laws of planetary motion describe the orbits of planets in a solar system, including Despina’s orbit, which takes 0.33 Earth days on average.

questions.correct: Among Neptune’s fourteen moons is Despina, which completes its orbit of the planet in 0.33 Earth days on average.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • An isthmus is a strip of land that connects two larger pieces of land across an expanse of water.
  • It is also known as a land bridge. The Isthmus of Panama is located in Central America.
  • It connects North America to South America. The Isthmus of Ierapetra is located in the Mediterranean Sea.
  • It connects the Siteia municipality to the rest of the island of Crete.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize a difference between the Isthmus of Panama and the Isthmus of Ierapetra. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: The Isthmus of Ierapetra is an isthmus, or land bridge.

options.name: B
options.content: The Isthmus of Panama is located in Central America, while the Isthmus of Ierapetra is located in the Mediterranean Sea.

options.name: C
options.content: There is an isthmus, or land bridge, located in Central America.

options.name: D
options.content: An isthmus, or land bridge, is a strip of land that connects two larger pieces of land across an expanse of water.

questions.correct: The Isthmus of Panama is located in Central America, while the Isthmus of Ierapetra is located in the Mediterranean Sea.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Columbia Trail is a rail trail.
  • It is located in New Jersey.
  • The Flint Hills Trail is a rail trail.
  • It is located in Kansas.
  • Rail trails are former railroad corridors that have been converted into public paths.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize a similarity between the Columbia Trail and the Flint Hills Trail. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: The Columbia Trail is in New Jersey, whereas the Flint Hills Trail is in Kansas.

options.name: B
options.content: A former railroad corridor, the Columbia Trail is located in New Jersey.

options.name: C
options.content: Both the Columbia Trail and the Flint Hills Trail are rail trails.

options.name: D
options.content: A public path created from a former railroad corridor can be found in Kansas.

questions.correct: Both the Columbia Trail and the Flint Hills Trail are rail trails.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • On Earth We’re Briefly Gorgeous (2019) is an epistolary novel by American author Ocean Vuong.
  • Epistolary novels are novels written primarily as a series of fictional documents.
  • These documents can be letters, journal entries, newspaper clippings, and more.
  • On Earth We’re Briefly Gorgeous consists primarily of letters.
  • The letters are sent from a young man named Little Dog to his mother, Rose.
questions.question: The student wants to provide an example of an epistolary novel. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: In 2019, American author Ocean Vuong published a novel of letters sent from a young man named Little Dog to his mother, Rose.

options.name: B
options.content: Consisting primarily of letters sent from a young man named Little Dog to his mother, Rose, Ocean Vuong’s On Earth We’re Briefly Gorgeous is an epistolary novel.

options.name: C
options.content: It was Ocean Vuong who published the novel On Earth We’re Briefly Gorgeous in 2019.

options.name: D
options.content: An epistolary novel is a novel written primarily as a series of fictional documents, such as letters, journal entries, or newspaper clippings.

questions.correct: Consisting primarily of letters sent from a young man named Little Dog to his mother, Rose, Ocean Vuong’s On Earth We’re Briefly Gorgeous is an epistolary novel.
